comments.commentBody: I had a true bon voyage tonight even if there was no return.  I think this particular crossword made me a 'million worder' and entitles me to one free crossword.

@egoldgold: DUNEBUGGY is the answer you seek. Hope it gets you unstuck and on your way. Perhaps you should look at the starting hint, if you haven't yet.

The symmetry wasn't the original part, the shading/circles was.

All Japanese syllables end with a vowel. The "n" is not an exception; it's a "nasalizer" and not really a consonant at the end of a syllable

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiragana

Believe it or not, diagramless fans or would-be fans, someone has gone to the trouble of developing an ingenious piece of free (!) software to aid in solving diagramless puzzles, called Diagnil (http://blueherons.org/diagnil/ ). It runs in Windows, Mac, and Linux OSes. One particular stroke of genius is that it opens an Across Lite diagramless file without revealing the finished grid. You can work in the grid, or enter clue answers in the Across and Down clue lists and then drag them to the grid. End black squares are placed automatically, and if there's a known symmetry to the puzzle, it can be set to automatically place symmetric black squares. Another masterstroke is that it lets you pick up whole sections of crossed words and move them elsewhere in the grid (try doing that on graph paper). Having searched the Wordplay blog and the XWord Info site, but finding no mention of it, I thought the word needed to be spread in this forum. If you take a little time to familiarize yourself with the software's interface and its features, I think you'll come to appreciate what an amazing tool it is. I'm going back and unearthing all the past diagramlesses that I was saving for a rainy day.

Interesting recap (on an NFL blog) of the world cup to date.....just because it's my site doesn't mean I'm biased.....

Germany put on quite a show....could have gone for 7 or 8. Australia looks like they do not belong here. But, I still like what I saw from SK.
What is the obsession of pointing out every players lineage. This is the Times, we should be comfortable with immigrants, American or German, no?
Its hygienic but lacks the zing that a roadside vada-pav can offer.

@46" It is ironic also how some of the smaller stars didn't bother to come to the rehearsals but folks like Antonio Banderas, Helen Mirren, Paula Abdul and Miss Broadway herself, Angela Landsbury were there bright, early and energetic."
Hi 46. I don't think it is a case of 'didn't bother" so much as scheduling. Lotta matinees. And Ms Lansbury is such a hand that she can probably turn up for her matinee 30 minutes before curtain!
What?  Zeta Jones won over Sherie Rene Scott.  That's an all time low for the Tony's.  That pretentious wannabe cannot sing nor act.  She should not do SONDHEIM again ever.

It doesn't matter that the show was terrible, other than a few New York theater fanatics, nobody watches it. One reason why national interest (which was never high to begin with) has really dropped off is that Broadway (like television and cinema) is driven by the money changers. It is obvious that they are trying to put more butts in the seats by loading up the casts with Hollywood types many of whom are definitely square pegs driven into round holes with a big roll of quarters. I don't dispute all of this year's awards (DW and VD were really good in FENCES). But SJ was less than electrifying in A VIEW FROM A BRIDGE and Catherine Zeta Jones did not set the stage on fire in her musical. I would also have given the Tony to Sahra Ngaijah in his category by virtue of the fact that he is on stage almost non stop for three and half hours singing, dancing, playing a hundred instruments, etc. He did everything  except work the spot lights. The other nominees were pretty tame in comparison. Also, if they can't give a regular Tony to the great Alfred Molina, then they should come up with some sort of life time achievement award-first installment for this superb actor who has done tremendous work both as an artist as well as an all around supporter of live theater in general. He is held in the highest regard by fans and fellow performers alike.

RED is an eye opener to me as I have a better understanding of the work of Rothko.  Simply as a play- it is beyond fantastic.  I enjoy the theater so much and this season has been great.  RACE, View from the Bridge, and of course, I am catching some musicals too!  Great joy the theater brings to my life.

I absolutely love the sabudana vadas. They are non-oily, spicy and big as a tennis ball. Misal is good too, a tad too hot for my taste buds. Love the sight of servers donning the gandhi topi. Prakash is truly keeping the essence of Maharashtra alive!

Zeta Jones? Go back to Bermuda. What an affront to all the great actresses who have won this award. Wonder how much it cost?
Is Broadway building a new theater?

Sad to see that tremendously heartfelt performance by Zeta-Jones being so trashed.
Maybe Newsweek should do a piece on theater critics and their lemmings.

Best speech of the night: Viola Davis. Electrifying. Unlike her co-star, Denzel Washington, who sort of acted like he really didn't give a rip, or maybe he was just trying to underplay the moment for some reason. I also found Catherine Z-J's performance to be somewhat odd (and off key), and was disappointed that there wasn't more made of Sondheim, one of the greatest theater composers of all time, and his 80th birthday.

Did I miss something or what were Beyonce and Jay-Z doing there?  Lots of "stars" in the audience (and presenting onstage), but why so much face-time for this couple?  And speaking of star appeal, Montego Glover probably deserved the award for Best Actress in a Musical, but CZJ made a credible Broadway debut and should get a prize for looking INcredible.  Star presence isn't as easy to achieve as some might think and it's pretty much a requirement for playing Desiree Armfeldt.

We treat the World Cup in a similar manner as we do the Olympics. Every four years a world captivating sporting event takes place during which there is little exposure to the general public since the previous event. Skiing and ice skating and gymnastics are all complicated sports. Each appear simple on the surface but subtle nuances and technical differences separate first from last and gold, silver and bronze. How often does NBC (the reigning Olympic content provider) break away from live coverage to educate the populace about what to look for and where the athletes will differentiate themselves when competing; this particular turn on the downhill course or that section of the bobsled track will cleave the competitors into winners and losers. We tolerate that level of simplistic coverage because few people follow the international track and field scene or skeleton or (insert Olympic sport here) to be knowledgeable fans.

Many more people play soccer than downhill ski race or competitively ice skate which means the sport literacy level is higher. How much higher is up for debate. We have Major League Soccer and slowly English Premiere League (the baseball equivalent of the Major Leagues) teams are holding 'friendly matches' (games that do not count against their league records) here in the US. This is bring wider exposure to high quality soccer. It's similar when the NFL sent two teams to Japan for a pre-season game a few years ago.

What this means it's up to fans to show team owners and the sponsors that soccer is important to the US by selling out games; watching it on TV and joining local leagues to play. If we as consumers only express interest in soccer when the World Cup comes around, the content delivered by the networks will be poor and largely geared towards illiterate viewers. However, if we demonstrate a deeper love for soccer we might see better coverage. Lastly, there are books and videos we can proactively seek to better educate ourselves on the game.
No comment from the company or officials about whether the workers' claims were true?

Despite ESPN/ABC's attempt to act like the World Cup is the culmination of the journey which began with the fight against apartheid, the truth is that FIFA and the Olympics fly around the world blackmailing countries into building these gleaming palaces of sport, which oftentimes leave countries, even rich countries, saddled with years of debt.  Doubters need only google Montreal and Olympics.  I shudder to think what will happen in Brazil with the double whammy of the World Cup followed by the Olympics.  Instead of worrying about whether FIFA wants heated toilet seats in their hotel rooms, these countries should be focusing on doing what they're doing best--helping the rest of the debt-ridden world to escape this economic recession.  Having said that, I hope Paraguay beats the snot out of Italy.

First goal by Podolski was NOT off-side. Our player was on-side...however the other german player was soft-offside and even THEN, the pass wasn't directed at him. Therefore, the through-ball in the penalty area was legitimate leading to Poldi's powerful kick and goal via deflection off Shwartzer's glove into the top-left corner.

Great performance against an aging team. Though our team looks great, we've yet to be measured against true teams. Aussies shouldn't have been in this tournament. They're a 3rd tier team at best. If Germany performs this good against the likes of the Dutch, Portuguese, Brazilians...then perhaps we can say we are the best. Until this point in the WM2010, wir sind die besten! Deutschland ueber alles...!!!!

- Farooq...an American who loves Germany (PS, I'm also a Bayern Muenchen fan as well)

Look at the video and you see that while Heskey is going for the ball he arrives late and makes no contact with the ball but flies into Howard with his studs showing.  No foul or card is given.  If Gooch had done this to Green, the British commentary would not be defending it as they did.  Time to get rid of them and get our own saying something far more impartial than a Brit pedant.  Do refs favor the 'big' soccer nations?  Best image to be retained long term was Robert Green (representing the entire English nation) on his knees with his head resting on the pitch.  Pure poetry!

How many countries have had players on their national team during the last 12 months who were born in Brazil or of Brazilian descent?

At least these:

Mexico
Germany
Spain
Portugal
Japan
Brasil
I am really interested in knowing the name of the hirer, and/or who in the SouthAfrican WC organisers let it come to this scandalous behaviour.
